dt: {bc}to succeed in reaching (a stage in a progression)

dt.t: would starve before {wi}accomplishing{/wi} half the distance

pt: {sc}perform{/sc} {sc}execute{/sc} {sc}discharge{/sc} {sc}accomplish{/sc} {sc}achieve{/sc} {sc}effect{/sc} {sc}fulfill{/sc} mean to carry out or into effect. {sc}perform{/sc} implies action that follows established patterns or procedures or fulfills agreed-upon requirements and often connotes special skill.
{sc}execute{/sc} stresses the carrying out of what exists in plan or in intent.
{sc}discharge{/sc} implies execution and completion of appointed duties or tasks.
{sc}accomplish{/sc} stresses the successful completion of a process rather than the means of carrying it out.

pt.t: {it}accomplished{/it} everything they set out to do

pt: {sc}achieve{/sc} adds to {sc}accomplish{/sc} the implication of conquered difficulties.
{sc}effect{/sc} adds to {sc}achieve{/sc} an emphasis on the inherent force in the agent capable of surmounting obstacles.
{sc}fulfill{/sc} implies a complete realization of ends or possibilities.

et: Middle English {it}acomplicen, accomplisshen{/it}, borrowed from Anglo-French {it}acomplis-{/it}, stem of {it}acomplir, acumplir{/it}, from {it}a-{/it}, prefix forming transitive verbs (going back to Latin {it}ad-{/it} {et_link|ad-|ad-}) + {it}complir, cumplir{/it} "to complete, fulfill," going back (with conjugation change) to Latin {it}complēre{/it} "to fill up, complete" {ma}{mat|complete:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: to bring about (a result) by effort
to succeed in reaching (a stage in a progression)
